answer_html: In conclusion, the work done by the ants to build the anthill is \(\frac{25\pi}{8} ft\cdot lb\).
answer_latex:
In conclusion, the work done by the ants to build the anthill is
$\frac{25\pi}{8} ft\cdot lb$.
hints_html: Split the cone up into cylinders with infinitely small height and add up the volume of these cylinders using integration.
hints_latex:
Split the cone up into cylinders with infinitely small height and add up
the volume of these cylinders using integration.
hints_raw: Split the cone up into cylinders with infinitely small height and add up the volume of these cylinders using integration.
sols_html:
Consider the diagram for building the anthill . We can think of building the hill as stacking several small cylinders of height \(\Delta{}x\) or \(\textrm{d}x\) (thinking forward to integration) from the ground (x=1) to the top (x=0). Consider the anthill at some intermediate distance from the top x (at a distance 1-x from the ground). This point is represented in the diagram as \(x_i^*\). The volume of a new cylinder to add onto the anthill will be

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}dV=\pi{}(r(x))^2\textrm{d}x\end{aligned}\]

where dx is the height of the cylinder and r(x) is the radius of the anthill at the current height. There is a similar triangle problem between the top of the completed anthill and the current disk we’re looking at and so we can determine the radius at our current height x via

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{1/2} = \frac{x}{r(x)}\end{aligned}\]

and so

\[\begin{aligned} r(x) = \frac{x}{2}.\end{aligned}\]

Notice that indeed when we’re at the top (x=0) then the radius is zero and when we’re at the bottom (x=1) that the radius is 1/2. We therefore have that the new amount of sand volume we are adding is

\[\begin{aligned} dV=\frac{\pi}{4}x^2\textrm{d}x.\end{aligned}\]

In the problem we are given a density \(150lb/ft^3\) which is actually a force density because lbs is a measure of force. This is telling us the force required to lift sand of a given volume which is precisely what we are trying to do with our cylinder of sand and so the force required to lift it is

 force = force density \(\times\) volume 

\[\begin{aligned} dF=150dV=\frac{150\pi}{4}x^2\textrm{d}x.\end{aligned}\]

The work required to lift this cylinder to its position in the hill at x will be this force dF multiplied with the height we have to lift it from the ground 1-x. Therefore the amount of work to lift this cylinder is

\[\begin{aligned} dW=(1-x)dF=\frac{150\pi}{4}x^2(1-x)\textrm{d}x.\end{aligned}\]

This is the work to build one small cylinder. The whole hill is built by adding cylinders for all values of x and so to get the total work we integrate

\[\begin{aligned} \text{work} =\int_0^1\textrm{d}W &= \int_0^1 \frac{150\pi}{4} x^2\,(1-x) dx\\ &= \left[\frac{150\pi x^3}{12} - \frac{150\pi x^4}{16}\right]_0^1 \\ &= \frac{150 \pi}{12} -\frac{150\pi }{16} \\ &= \frac{25\pi}{8}\end{aligned}\]

Let us do a quick sanity check on the units to see if we have missed out anything.

The volume is in \(ft^3\), and the density is given in \(lb / ft^3\), so the weight is in \(lb\), finally work is force (weight) times distance (which is in \(ft\)), so we get our work to be in \(ft\cdot lb\), which is right.

In conclusion, the work done by the ants to build the anthill is \(\frac{25\pi}{8} ft\cdot lb\).
sols_latex:
Consider the diagram for building the anthill
\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH101/April_2010/MATH101_April_2010_Question_4_Cone.png}. We can think
of building the hill as stacking several small cylinders of height
$\Delta{}x$ or $\textrm{d}x$ (thinking forward to integration) from the
ground (\emph{x=1}) to the top (\emph{x=0}). Consider the anthill at
some intermediate distance from the top x (at a distance \emph{1-x} from
the ground). This point is represented in the diagram as $x_i^*$. The
volume of a new cylinder to add onto the anthill will be

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}dV=\pi{}(r(x))^2\textrm{d}x
\end{align*}

where \emph{dx} is the height of the cylinder and \emph{r(x)} is the
radius of the anthill at the current height. There is a similar triangle
problem between the top of the completed anthill and the current disk
we're looking at \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH101/April_2010/Math101Apr10Q4-similartri.png} and so
we can determine the radius at our current height \emph{x} via

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{1/2} = \frac{x}{r(x)}
\end{align*}

and so

\begin{align*}
r(x) = \frac{x}{2}.
\end{align*}

Notice that indeed when we're at the top (\emph{x=0}) then the radius is
zero and when we're at the bottom (\emph{x=1}) that the radius is 1/2.
We therefore have that the new amount of sand volume we are adding is

\begin{align*}
dV=\frac{\pi}{4}x^2\textrm{d}x.
\end{align*}

In the problem we are given a density $150lb/ft^3$ which is actually a
\textbf{force} density because lbs is a measure of force. This is
telling us the force required to lift sand of a given volume which is
precisely what we are trying to do with our cylinder of sand and so the
force required to lift it is

\texttt{~force~=~force~density~}$\times$\texttt{~volume~}

\begin{align*}
dF=150dV=\frac{150\pi}{4}x^2\textrm{d}x.
\end{align*}

The work required to lift this cylinder to its position in the hill at
\emph{x} will be this force \emph{dF} multiplied with the height we have
to lift it from the ground \emph{1-x}. Therefore the amount of work to
lift this cylinder is

\begin{align*}
dW=(1-x)dF=\frac{150\pi}{4}x^2(1-x)\textrm{d}x.
\end{align*}

This is the work to build one small cylinder. The whole hill is built by
adding cylinders for all values of \emph{x} and so to get the total work
we integrate

\begin{align*}
\text{work} =\int_0^1\textrm{d}W &= \int_0^1  \frac{150\pi}{4} x^2\,(1-x) dx\\
&= \left[\frac{150\pi x^3}{12} - \frac{150\pi x^4}{16}\right]_0^1 \\
&= \frac{150 \pi}{12} -\frac{150\pi }{16} \\
&= \frac{25\pi}{8}
\end{align*}

Let us do a quick sanity check on the units to see if we have missed out
anything.

The volume is in $ft^3$, and the density is given in $lb / ft^3$, so the
weight is in $lb$, finally work is force (weight) times distance (which
is in $ft$), so we get our work to be in $ft\cdot lb$, which is right.

In conclusion, the work done by the ants to build the anthill is
$\frac{25\pi}{8} ft\cdot lb$.
sols_raw:
Consider the diagram for building the anthill [[File:MATH101_April_2010_Question_4_Cone.png|500px|thumbnail|right]].  We can think of building the hill as stacking several small cylinders of height <math>\Delta{}x</math> or <math>\textrm{d}x</math> (thinking forward to integration) from the ground (''x=1'') to the top (''x=0'').  Consider the anthill at some intermediate distance from the top x (at a distance ''1-x'' from the ground).  This point is represented in the diagram as <math>x_i^*</math>.  The volume of a new cylinder to add onto the anthill will be

:<math>
\displaystyle{}dV=\pi{}(r(x))^2\textrm{d}x
</math>

where ''dx'' is the height of the cylinder and ''r(x)'' is the radius of the anthill at the current height.  There is a similar triangle problem between the top of the completed anthill and the current disk we're looking at [[File:Math101Apr10Q4-similartri.png|1000px|thumbnail|right|Similar triangle problem for the anthill]] and so we can determine the radius at our current height ''x'' via

:<math>
\frac{1}{1/2} = \frac{x}{r(x)}
</math>

and so

:<math>
r(x) = \frac{x}{2}.
</math>

Notice that indeed when we're at the top (''x=0'') then the radius is zero and when we're at the bottom (''x=1'') that the radius is 1/2.  We therefore have that the new amount of sand volume we are adding is

:<math>
dV=\frac{\pi}{4}x^2\textrm{d}x.
</math>

In the problem we are given a density <math>150lb/ft^3</math> which is actually a '''force''' density because lbs is a measure of force.  This is telling us the force required to lift sand of a given volume which is precisely what we are trying to do with our cylinder of sand and so the force required to lift it is

  force = force density <math> \times </math> volume 

:<math>
dF=150dV=\frac{150\pi}{4}x^2\textrm{d}x.
</math>

The work required to lift this cylinder to its position in the hill at ''x'' will be this force ''dF'' multiplied with the height we have to lift it from the ground ''1-x''.  Therefore the amount of work to lift this cylinder is

:<math>
dW=(1-x)dF=\frac{150\pi}{4}x^2(1-x)\textrm{d}x.
</math>

This is the work to build one small cylinder.  The whole hill is built by adding cylinders for all values of ''x'' and so to get the total work we integrate

:<math>\begin{align}
\text{work} =\int_0^1\textrm{d}W &= \int_0^1  \frac{150\pi}{4} x^2\,(1-x) dx\\
&= \left[\frac{150\pi x^3}{12} - \frac{150\pi x^4}{16}\right]_0^1 \\
&= \frac{150 \pi}{12} -\frac{150\pi }{16} \\
&= \frac{25\pi}{8}
\end{align}</math>

Let us do a quick sanity check on the units to see if we have missed out anything. 

The volume is in <math>ft^3</math>, and the density is given in <math> lb / ft^3 </math>, so the weight is in <math> lb </math>, finally work is force (weight) times distance (which is in <math> ft </math>), so we get our work to be in <math> ft\cdot lb </math>, which is right.

In conclusion, the work done by the ants to build the anthill is <math> \frac{25\pi}{8} ft\cdot lb </math>.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answer and show all your work. Simplification of the answer is not required.

A colony of ants builds an anthill that is in the shape of a cone whose base, at ground level, is a circle of diameter 1 ft and whose height is also 1 ft. How much total work, in ft\(\cdot\)lbs, is done by the ants in building the anthill? For the density of sand, use the value \(150\, \text{lb}/\text{ft}^3.\)
statement_latex:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answer and \textbf{show all
your work.} Simplification of the answer is not required.

A colony of ants builds an anthill that is in the shape of a cone whose
base, at ground level, is a circle of \emph{diameter} 1 ft and whose
height is also 1 ft. How much total work, in ft$\cdot$lbs, is done by
the ants in building the anthill? For the density of sand, use the value
$150\, \text{lb}/\text{ft}^3.$

'''Full-Solution Problem.''' Justify your answer and '''show all your work.''' Simplification of the answer is not required.

A colony of ants builds an anthill that is in the shape of a cone whose base, at ground level, is a circle of ''diameter'' 1 ft and whose height is also 1 ft. How much total work, in ft<math>\cdot</math>lbs, is done by the ants in building the anthill? For the density of sand, use the value <math> 150\, \text{lb}/\text{ft}^3. </math>
